thread.title: Medicaid Expansion Could Be On South Dakota's Horizon
thread.title_full: Medicaid Expansion Could Be On South Dakota's Horizon

title: Medicaid Expansion Could Be On South Dakota's Horizon
text:
Working Out Before Hunting Season October 8, 2015, 6:19 PM by Casey Wonnenberg SIOUX FALLS, SD - 
Instead of target shooting, 61-year-old Gary Tuschen is aiming for a good hunt by getting into shape. 
"For me, it's pretty much every day," Tuschen said. "Getting fit or staying fit definitely enhances the hunting experience." 
Thankfully, Tushen hasn't witnessed a heart attack while hunting, but he has noticed people who aren't physically prepared. 
"The day's experience ends up getting compromised," Tuschen said. "Then at the end of the day when you want to have time with your family and friends and exchange that pleasantry, you're fatigued. You have aches and pains, and you're snoring at 8." 
What exercise should hunters shoot for? Personal trainer Chad Gomarko recommends working out at least 30 minutes a day, with a mix of cardio, weight training and stability exercises. 
"If you're not doing anything, I would start slow with ten minutes. Work up to 15. Gradually add in an incline and intervals," Gomarko said. 
If you haven't had a chance to hit the gym, you can take steps the day of the hunt to help prevent injuries. 
"With the walking necessary for hunting, make sure you understand how to monitor your heart rate," Gomarko said. 
Chances are you don't carry a heart rate monitor with you, so pay attention to how you're talking to fellow hunters. 
"When you get to the point of cardiovascular exercise that you can't talk, you're probably at the point that you're stressing your body. If you can carry on a normal conversation, you're probably not working out hard enough," Gomarko said. 
Thanks to hours at the gym, Tuschen feels prepared to carry on his hunting tradition with his brothers. 
"You're lugging a gun all day long. It's easier if you have a little strength," Tuschen said. "Now I've got son-in-laws and grandkids, so I have four generations that I'm with. It's pretty fun," Tuschen said. Â© 2015 KELOLAND TV. All Rights Reserved.
